text:
Raskolnikov walked into the room, trying hard not to laugh again. Behind him, Razumihin came in awkwardly, looking embarrassed and red like a flower, with a fierce expression. He looked so silly that it made Raskolnikov laugh even more.

Without waiting for an introduction, Raskolnikov bowed to Porfiry Petrovitch, who was standing in the middle of the room, looking at them curiously. He reached out his hand to shake hands, still trying hard to stop laughing and say a few words to introduce himself. Just when he managed to look serious and say something, he glanced at Razumihin again and couldn’t hold back his laughter. The more he tried to stop, the more he laughed.

Razumihin’s angry reaction made the whole situation seem really funny and natural. He added to this feeling on purpose by shouting, “Fool! You fiend!” while waving his arm, which accidentally hit a small table with an empty tea-glass on it. Everything went flying and broke. 

“But why break chairs, gentlemen? You know it’s a loss to…”

**PAGE SUMMARY:** Raskolnikov struggles to contain his laughter at Razumihin's awkwardness during their entrance into Porfiry Petrovitch's room.
